title.bibl: Dziennik Chicagoski, Oct. 25, 1897. Pole Gets Postal Substation

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from digital images contributed to the Internet Archive by the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

sourceDesc.bibl: Chicago Foreign Language Press Survey, 1936-1941, Works Projects Administration, Chicago Public Library Omnibus Project

revisionDesc.change: Initial TEI transcription from PanGeo Partners, Inc.

div.bibl: Dziennik Chicagoski, Oct. 25, 1897. POLE GETS POSTAL SUBSTATION

body.p: I am proud to announce to the Polish public that I have been given charge of a postal substation in my home at 924 West 33rd Street. All services of a regular postal station are offered--money orders, registered mail, mailing of packages, post cards, stamps, etc. Polish, Lithuanian, and English spoken. Office hours: 7 A. M. to 9 P. M.; Sundays, 10 A. M. to 7 P. M.
The Polish public is invited to patronize this substation during the above-mentioned hours.
